poem:
**Flight of the Orange-bellied Parrots**

Against the sweep of Bass Strait's breath,  
six dots in a vast sky arrive,  
wings as small as an afterthought,  
dancing on the edge of extinction.  
Their orange whispers spread  
among the trees. Secrets,  
they carry on timid voices,  
filling the wind  
with hopeful echoes.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Orange-bellied parrots have swelled back from imminent extinction – but now they face a new threat One of Australia’s most critically endangered bird species has started arriving at Melaleuca, in Tasmania’s south-western world heritage area. By late this week, six orange-bellied parrots had turned up at the remote outpost to breed, having made the weeks-long flight from the mainland, across Bass Strait and down the state’s wild west coast. Relatively little is known about where". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
